ca.uqac.lif.cep

Class Processor

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.uqac.lif.cep.Processor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Contextualizable, Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    GroupProcessor, Multiplexer, SingleProcessor, SmartFork

    public abstract class Processor
extends Object
implements Cloneable, Contextualizable
    Receives zero or more input events, and produces zero or more output events. The processor is the fundamental class where all computation occurs. All of BeepBeep's processors (including yours) are descendants of this class.

    This class itself is abstract; nevertheless, it provides important methods for handling input/output event queues, connecting processors together, etc. However, if you write your own processor, you will most likely want to inherit from its child, SingleProcessor, which does some more work for you.

    The Processor class does not assume anything about the type of events being input or output. All its input and output queues are therefore declared as containing instances of Object, Java's most generic type.

    Author:
    Sylvain Hallé

    • Field Detail

      • m_inputArity

        protected int m_inputArity
        The processor's input arity, i.e. the number of input events it requires to produce an output

      • m_outputArity

        protected int m_outputArity
        The processor's output arity, i.e. the number of output events it produces

      • m_inputQueues

        protected Queue<Object>[] m_inputQueues
        An array of input event queues. This is where the input events will be stored before the processor consumes them. There are as many input queues as the input arity of the processor.

      • m_outputQueues

        protected Queue<Object>[] m_outputQueues
        An array of output event queues. This is where the output events will be stored when the processor does its computation. There are as many output queues as the output arity of the processor.

      • m_inputPullables

        protected Pullable[] m_inputPullables
        An array of Pullables, one for each input trace this processor receives

      • m_outputPushables

        protected Pushable[] m_outputPushables
        An array of Pushables, one for each output trace this processor produces

      • s_uniqueIdCounter

        protected static int s_uniqueIdCounter
        A static counter, to be incremented every time a new Processor is instantiated. This is used to give a unique integer number to every processor.

      • m_uniqueId

        protected int m_uniqueId
        The unique ID given to this processor instance

      • m_context

        protected Context m_context
        The context in which the processor is instantiated

    • Constructor Detail

      • Processor

        public Processor(int in_arity,
         int out_arity)
        Initializes a processor. This has for effect of executing the basic operations common to every processor:
        • Giving a unique ID
        • Determining its input and output arity
        • Creating arrays of empty input and output queues, as well as arrays of Pullables and Pushables

        If you create your own processor, its constructor must start by calling its ancestor's constructor (which ultimately ends up calling this constructor). Otherwise, expect a plethora of null pointers and other oddities.

        Parameters:
        in_arity - The processor's input arity
        out_arity - The processor's output arity

      • getId

        Fetches the processor instance's unique ID
        Returns:
        The ID

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Resets the processor. This has for effect of flushing the contents of all input and output event queues. If the processor has an internal state, this should also reset this state to its "initial" settings (whatever that means in your context).

      • getPushableInput

        public abstract Pushable getPushableInput(int index)
        Returns the Pushable corresponding to the processor's i-th input trace.
        Parameters:
        index - The index. Should be between 0 and the processor's input arity - 1 (since indices start at 0).
        Returns:
        The pushable if the index is within the appropriate range, null otherwise.

      • getPullableOutput

        public abstract Pullable getPullableOutput(int index)
        Returns the Pullable corresponding to the processor's i-th output trace.
        Parameters:
        index - The index. Should be between 0 and the processor's output arity - 1 (since indices start at 0).
        Returns:
        The pullable if the index is within the appropriate range, null otherwise.

      • setPullableInput

        public void setPullableInput(int i,
                    Pullable p)
        Assigns a Pullable to the processor's i-th input.
        Parameters:
        i - The index of the input
        p - The pullable to assign it to

      • getPullableInput

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        The pullable

      • setPushableOutput

        public void setPushableOutput(int i,
                     Pushable p)
        Assigns a Pushable to the processor's i-th output.
        Parameters:
        i - The index of the output. Should be greater than 0 (not checked) and less than the processor's output arity. Outside these bounds, nothing will occur.
        p - The pushable to assign it to

      • getPushableOutput

        public Pushable getPushableOutput(int i)
        Retrieves the Pushable associated to the processor's i-th output.
        Parameters:
        i - The index of the output. Should be greater than 0 (not checked) and less than the processor's output arity. Outside these bounds, nothing will occur.
        Returns:
        The pushable, null if i is out of range

      • allNull

        public static boolean allNull(Object[] v)
        Checks if all objects in the array are null. This is a convenience method used by other processor classes (e.g. SingleProcessor to make sure that some output was generated from a given input
        Parameters:
        v - The array
        Returns:
        true if all elements in the array are null, false otherwise

      • liftProcessor

        public static Processor liftProcessor(Object o)
        Extracts a processor out of the object passed as an argument. A instance of Processor will be returned as is, while other objects will be wrapped into a constant processor returning that object.
        Parameters:
        o - The input object
        Returns:
        A processor

      • clone

        public abstract Processor clone()
        Overrides:
        clone in class Object

      • getInputType

        public final Set<Class<?>> getInputType(int index)
        Gets the type of events the processor accepts for its i-th input trace. Note that this method returns a set, in the case where the processor accepts various types of objects (for example, a processor accepting Numbers, but also Strings it converts into numbers internally).
        Parameters:
        index - The index of the input to query
        Returns:
        A set of classes. If index it less than 0 or greater than the processor's declared input arity, the set will be empty.

      • getInputTypesFor

        public void getInputTypesFor(Set<Class<?>> classes,
                    int index)
        Populates the set of classes accepted by the processor for its i-th input
        Parameters:
        classes - The set of to fill with classes
        index - The index of the input to query

      • getOutputType

        public final Class<?> getOutputType(int index)
        Gets the type of events the processor produces for its i-th output trace.
        Parameters:
        index - The index of the output to query
        Returns:
        A set of classes. If index it less than 0 or greater than the processor's declared output arity, the response will be null.

      • getOutputTypeFor

        public Class<?> getOutputTypeFor(int index)
        Returns the type of the events produced by the processor for its i-th output
        Parameters:
        index - The index of the output to query
        Returns:
        The type of the output
